items.content_html:
While far from perfect this offers some guidance for setting up a cluster with Ceph. It is intentionally not a step-by-step guide however. The NixOS Tests can fill the gap of a step-by-step guide, however upstream documentation and recommendations may change. If for instance the permissions required by a service such as an MGR ever tighten in the upstream documentation it would be great if users used that updated upstream documentation even if the tests have not caught on.

items.content_html:
I recently helped a user trying to install nixos via the NIXOS_LUSTRATE method described in the manual, who ran into some rather glaring issues, which have apparently existed for an embarassingly long time without being addressed (#49520), so I took it upon myself to improve the situation.

  • Altered switch-to-configuration.pl so that when the action is boot, it does not complain when /run/current-system/sw/bin does not exist.
  • Rewrote the main install step of the relevant section of the manual to:
    • Include the necessary NIXOS_INSTALL_BOOTLOADER variable
    • Alter the backup mechanism used in the code block to correctly handle cases where /boot is a mount point
    • Explain enough to hopefully handle cases where the given commands won't work verbatim

Closes #49520.

Note that I have not actually tested these instructions, and that should definitely happen before merge, but from second-hand reports, it should be correct... hopefully.

items.title: nixos/kmonad: init

items.content_html:
Improving NixOS Zapret module.

Now that #347805 got merged, which contained basic implementation, it's time to discuss possible QoL and functionality improvements. I'll draw some ideas bellow, yet I'm open to suggestions.

Again, those are just ideas to discuss. Or just leave the module as is to keep it simple?

Better http processing.

Current implementation bypasses DPI that only tracks first packet within keep-alive session. It is fast, as it only requires processing of a single packet. But there are scenarios when DPI tracks all the packets. This needs a different approach of processing every packet. Should be slower in theory, tho I haven't tested it yet.

Straightforward solution is just to create an option for that. But I'm unsure as that'd either be dull "enable this if http doesn't work" or a description that is a bit too technical for the end user.

UDP support.

Discord was blocked in Russia recently and it uses UDP for RTC. Zapret (nfqws) supports UDP even tho configuration is much more complicated. Only issue with that now is the fact that Discord works fine for me. Which means that I need to do a field operation of testing on a public WiFi or someone else testing that for me. I prepared a draft of possible configuration. I am also not aware of any other blocked services that use UDP.

Pre-configured targets.

Not a great idea. Not universal and requires too much maintenance. Result doesn't worth the effort.

This is purely QoL, but it might be nice to have options for specific services, like Youtube, which could be enabled like that: 
services.zapret = {
  enable = true;
  target = {
    youtube.enable = true;
    discord.enable = true;
  };
};

It really should be called whitelist.<target> but I take the shame for missing that opportunity. Still it'd work as a whitelist by adding known domains to the whitelist - this does not include setting up params option (but might require enabling not yet available udpSupport option, which would likely append stuff to params). This solves the problem of finding all required domains for the service, i.e. Youtube requires 4 domains that are listed in whitelist example. But it introduces the problem of maintaining such lists.
The only issue I see is that it might not be universal for everyone, but still should cover most cases.

An alternative would be creating a Wiki page.
items.title: nixos/zapret: improvements

items.content_html:
bonsai project.

nixpkgs already has the package for bonsai, which is only usable as a client + daemon setup. until now, bonsai package users were presumably all configuring their own services. this provides that service component, generally.

i chose to implement this as a user service. that's because both the daemon and client components -- bonsaid and bonsaictl coordinate on a socket by using the XDG_RUNTIME_DIR environment variable. so, if either one is invoked by a different user, they fail to connect. one can't run bonsaid as root and bonsaictl as an ordinary user, for example. the only thing that made sense was to attach bonsaid to the user's service manager.

@MatthewCroughan has graciously agreed to test this module.

items.content_html:
This adds a basic module for setting up Niri and its related services/dependencies. Options for config.kdl should be made after #295211

I tested this with the following locally and it worked well :) 
{
  environment = {
    sessionVariables = {
      NIXOS_OZONE_WL = "1"; # Niri doesn't have native XWayland support
    };

    systemPackages = with pkgs; [
      alacritty
      fuzzel
      grim
      mako
      slurp
      swaylock
      xwayland-satellite
    ];
  };

  programs.niri.enable = true;

  services.greetd = {
    enable = true;
    settings = {
      default_session.command = toString [
        (lib.getExe pkgs.greetd.tuigreet)
        "--time"
      ];
    };
  };

}

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Module & associated tests for #346281.

Includes an RFC42 settings option using a custom parser based on znc's and support for multiple instances similar to authelia's module. The test is pretty basic and verifies routing functionality between 2 hosts with VPP acting as the router.

items.title: nixos/minidlna: refactor

items.content_html:
Description of changes

As proposed in #266290:

Introduce an "apply" script to NixOS, aimed at improving deployment processes for developers and power users. The script reduces SSH roundtrips and sudo invocations by refactoring deployment logic, moving systemd-run logic out of nixos-rebuild, and simplifying the management of the profile and actions on the target host. This change addresses limitations in nixos-rebuild and offers a more efficient backend for deployment tools

Observations and deviations from the original proposal:

  • initiating the installation of the bootloader

    This is already done by switch-to-configuration, and that's ok.

  • The new apply script will be called and packaged in multiple ways:

    * The `nixos-rebuild` package: For applying configurations that pre-date the toplevel/bin/apply script

    I have avoided this, to keep the new code path simple, devoid of conditional ssh calls.
    The equivalent code in nixos-rebuild is ok to go stale, because it is only needed for old releases anyway. We can remove that in, say, early 2026, when everyone has had more than enough time to migrate away from the unsupported releases.

  • system.build.apply [...] very optional

    Not done yet, and that's ok.

  • Interface

    • Extra parameter that allows pathToConfig to be specified

    Unnecessarily complicated, and very low value once apply can be assumed to exist in, e.g. in January

    • Extra: default action [...] TBD [...] should be postponed

    Not needed in this PR; feature creep; postponing

TODO:

  • update documentation about switch-to-configuration switch to reflect reality (of even before this PR), and/or point to apply instead.
  • release note

Context

  • Closes #266290
  • Closes #82851

items.content_html:
Use repart to build a hybridg GPT/BIOS image

One thing that is still annoying and that our repart image builder doesn't solve is that a NixOS image needs a /nix/var/nix/profiles/system entry for it to be valid. For now hacking this in runInLinuxVM together with installing GRUB bootloader

    • sandbox = true

    • made sure NixOS tests are linked to the relevant packages
  • Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD". Note: all changes have to be committed, also see nixpkgs-review usage
  • Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • 24.11 Release Notes (or backporting 23.11 and 24.05 Release notes)

    • (Module updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is significant

items.title: nixos/dhcpcd: update sandboxing options

items.content_html:
This option replaces the active runtime manifest in the user directory.
Games running through Steam's Pressure Vessel cannot read /etc so forcefully overriding the file every time the service starts, will allow those games to use Monado.

Things done

  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin
    • aarch64-darwin
  • For non-Linux: Is sandboxing enabled in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)

    • sandbox = true
